Topic.Title: how many revenue passengers have not been able to fly on the 787 since the grounding ?

Message.Msg: If 787s were scheduled for about one delivery per week, then that would be about another 5 non deliveries with all the associated loss of revenue to the airlines. Problem getting bigger and bigger each week.

Topic.Title: So what part of this “Quick”, “Standard”, “Compatible” fix seems like a good idea?

Message.Msg: its a stainless stee 1/2 inch thick box according to some \- here is a reuters extracy The proposed fix includes adding ceramic insulation between the cells of the battery to help keep cells cool and prevent a "thermal runaway" in which one cell overheats and triggers overheating in adjacent cells. It also includes building a stronger, larger stainless steel box with a venting tube to contain a fire and expel fumes outside the aircraft should a battery catch fire again, the sources said. In addition, the plan proposed wiring changes, self-torquing screws that won't come loose and battery alterations to prevent moisture and vibration problems, one of the sources said. So it will be a more than 70 pound box - perhaps missing an safe and arming system to prevent an accidental explosion if he drops the box. No doubt a 100 yard or more hazard area needs to be established, with at least one fire guard while on the tarmac. IR sensors on the chrome exhaust stacks tied to an auto alarm system powered by . . . . the gate area. With luck a 5 minute warning - but must protect emergency slide area. Its just a rumour that Boeing is licensing from GM the firebird trademark !!!

Message.Title: Proposal Has Airplane Passengers Plug in Their Cell Phones to Provide the Battery Power
Message.Msg: Passengers cannot use their cell phones on the plane anyway.

Message.Title: Looks Like BA Is Setting Up FAA as the Fall Guy If a Plane Should Crash
Message.Msg: Since FAA has approved all BA design flaws, it cannot be BA fault.

Topic.Title: Looks Like BA Is Setting Up FAA as the Fall Guy If a Plane Should Crash

Message.Msg: agreed, it will be FAA decision, and since the FAA supports and promotes the industry as well as acts as a regulator they have a dual purpose Too bad supporting the industry usually means allowing dangerous situations like the 737 rudder flutter caused by a sticking piston in a unit in the tail. the problem was known abut for years and the first excuse is pilot error then when the problems continued the temporary fix was to teachthe pilots to turn in the direction of the hard over tial to free the piston. And over years the upgraded part was retrofitted. It is called follow the money. If Boeing admitted to having a part that was certified but did nto work then Boeing would owe all airlines the cost of the grounding. The reason the 787 was more easy to ground was only 50 are flying so the cost is huge but acceptable for a while . This is a major problem , but with all the radio shack parts on the plane and lack of Boeing engineering control this plane will continue to have problems for years to follow after this , what 4th year of delays . This is not the end, but just another example of management failure. Remember this is just one of several delays over the past 4 years . Nothing new here .

Message.Title: Give it time. The 787 will fly again soon with a new battery pack and mods.
Message.Msg: Boeing has never produced an aircraft that would danger the lives of passengers. BA was willing at the onset of these battery problems to ground the aircraft once they had a handle on what was at stake. Peoples lives. Boeing and it's employees will solve the problems, with a little bit of humble pie, and get this new aircraft airborn again.

Topic.Title: Give it time. The 787 will fly again soon with a new battery pack and mods.

Message.Msg: I think the Albatross would have been a more appropriate name than the "Dreamliner." Don't you?

Topic.Title: Give it time. The 787 will fly again soon with a new battery pack and mods.

Message.Msg: My fellow pilots that have flown the 787 love the aircraft. Flight attendants love the aircraft. The passengers, prior to the battery fiasco, according to crew all members, raved about the aircraft and it's comforts. Yes right now it's an albatross to the present operators who have lost revenue and Boeing. But in the long run I think it will be the Dreamliner everyone had hoped for.
